chapter.htmlHeader: How common is it?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Eating disorders [Zipfel, 2015; Keski-Rahkonen, 2016; Bould, 2017a; NICE, 2017; FSRH, 2018; Royal College of Psychiatrists, 2019]

  • Estimates suggest that over 700,000 people in the UK have an eating disorder, 90% of whom are female.
    • This is likely an underestimate as many cases do not present to health services.
    • Eating disorders can develop at any age but risk of onset is highest for adolescents and young adults.
  • Atypical eating disorders are the most common, followed by binge eating disorders, and bulimia nervosa. Anorexia nervosa is the least common.
    • A systematic review including 94 studies (time period 2000-2018) looking at the prevalence of eating disorders globally found the weighted mean of [Galmiche, 2019]:
      • Lifetime eating disorders to be 8.4% (range 3.3–18.6%) for women and 2.2% (range 0.8–6.5%) for men.
      • Point prevalence of eating disorders to be 4.6% (range 2.0–13.5%) in America, 2.2% (range 0.2–13.1%) in Europe, and 3.5% (range 0.6–7.8%) in Asia.

Anorexia nervosa (AN) [Zipfel, 2015; Keski-Rahkonen, 2016; NICE, 2017; Berends, 2018]

  • The lifetime prevalence of AN in women is reported to be between 2–4%.
  • Incidence rates vary from 4.2–12.6 per 100,000 person-years for females to 1 per 100,000 person-years for males.
    • Overall incidence rates are around 6.0 per 100 000 population with highest incidence in people aged 15–19 years.
  • AN has a higher mortality rate than any other mental health disorder.
    • The weighted crude mortality rate for AN is around 5.1 deaths per 1,000 person-years — 20% of deaths in people with AN are due to suicide.

Bulimia nervosa (BN) [Lock, 2015; Keski-Rahkonen, 2016; NICE, 2017]

  • The prevalence of BN in Europe has been reported as less than 1–2%.
    • A systematic review including 94 studies (time period 2000-2018) looking at the prevalence of eating disorders worldwide found the weighted mean point prevalence for BN to be 1.5% (range 0–8.4%) for females and 0.1% (range 0–1.3%) for males [Galmiche, 2019].
  • Peak age of onset is in later adolescence and young adulthood (age 15—25 years).
  • The weighted crude mortality rate for BN is around 1.74 per 1,000 person-years.

Binge Eating disorder (BED) [Hay, 2014; NICE, 2017]

  • The estimated lifetime prevalence of BED in Europe is around 1.9% for women and 0.3% for men.
    • A systematic review including 94 studies (time period 2000-2018) looking at the prevalence of eating disorders worldwide found the weighted mean point prevalence of BED to be 2.3% (range 0–9.8%) for females and 0.3% (range 0–0.5%) for males [Galmiche, 2019].
  • BED is identified more often in males and at an older age than other eating disorders — it is often associated with obesity.

Atypical eating disorders (eating disorder not otherwise specified [EDNOS] or other specified feeding or eating disorder [OSFED]) [NICE, 2017]

  • Atypical cases form the largest single category of eating disorders.
    • A systematic review including 94 studies (time period 2000-2018) of prevalence of eating disorders found that the weighted mean point prevalence for EDNOS was 10.1% (range 0.5–31.1%) for females and 0.9% (range 0–1.7%) for men [Galmiche, 2019].
  • The lifetime prevalence of EDNOS in the US is estimated to be around 4.8% in young people and 4.6% in adults.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?
